36. Eigenfunction expansions and classical scattering theory

In this section we use our normalized eigenfunctions and scattering data in the selfadjoint case to sketch some standard constructions of spectral theory; see [[Na],[RS],[We]]. The basic tool is formula (10.8) for the bounded Greens function, which we repeat here.

Let $L$ be a generic selfadjoint operator with normalized eigenfunctions

36.1 $$\begin{equation} u_{j}(x, z)=m_{1j}(x, z)e^{ix\alpha _{j}z},\quad \alpha _{j}=\alpha _{j}(z), \cssId{texmlid636}{\tag{36.1}} \end{equation}$$

36.2$$\begin{equation} \tilde{u}_{j}(x, z)=\tilde{m}_{1j}(x, z)e^{ix\alpha _{j}z}=\delta _{j}(z)^{-1}u_{j}(x, z), \cssId{texmlid637}{\tag{36.2}} \end{equation}$$ $z\in \mathbf{C}\backslash (\Sigma \cup Z)$. The Greens function for $\lambda =z^{n}$ is then

36.3 $$\begin{align} G_{\lambda }(x,y)&=G(x,y, z)\cssId{texmlid638}{\tag{36.3}}\\ &=-\displaystyle \frac{i}{n}z^{1-n}\sum _{\mathrm{Re}(i\alpha _{j}z)>0}\alpha _{j}u_{j}(x,z)\overline{u_{n-j+1}(y,\overline{z})},\ \mathrm{for}\ x<y;\\ &=\displaystyle \frac{i}{n}z^{1-n}\sum _{\mathrm{Re}(i\alpha _{j}z)<0}\alpha _{j}u_{j}(x,z)\overline{u_{n-j+1}(y,\overline{z})},\ \mathrm{for}\ x>y, \end{align}$$

provided $\alpha _{j}z\not \in \mathbf{R}$, all $j$.

We consider first the case $n=2l+1$. The free operator $L_{0}=D^{n}$ has spectrum $\sigma (L_{0})=\mathbf{R}$, with multiplicity 1. The standard Fourier transform gives a diagonalizing map (eigenfunction expansion) for $L_{0}$:

36.4 $$\begin{equation} \mathscr{F}_{0}:L^{2}(\mathbf{R}, dx)\rightarrow L^{2}(\mathbf{R}, d\xi ), \cssId{texmlid639}{\tag{36.4}} \end{equation}$$

$$\begin{equation*} \mathscr{F}_{0}f(\xi )=\frac{1}{\sqrt {2\pi }}\int _{\mathbf{R}}e^{-ix\xi }f(x)dx\equiv \hat{f}(\xi ). \end{equation*}$$ This map is unitary:

36.5 $$\begin{equation} \mathscr{F}_{0}^{-1}g(x)=\mathscr{F}_{0}^{*}g(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt {2\pi }}\int _{\mathbf{R}}e^{ix\xi }g(\xi )d\xi . \cssId{texmlid640}{\tag{36.5}} \end{equation}$$

Such a diagonalization is unique up to a map from $\sigma (L_{0})$ to $U(1)$, the $1\times 1$ unitary group, since the spectrum is simple. As we shall see, the quantum mechanical wave operators single out two normalizations for diagonalizations of $L$ (which coincide with $\mathscr{F}_{0}$ when $L=L_{0}$).

We turn now to the even case, $n=2l$. Here the free operator $L_{0}$ has spectrum $\sigma (L_{0})=\overline{\mathbf{R}}_{0}$ with multiplicity 2. Once again the Fourier transform provides a diagonalizing map

36.21 $$\begin{align} \mathscr{F}_{e}:L^{2}(\mathbf{R}, dx)\rightarrow L^{2}(\mathbf{R}_{+}, d\xi )\oplus L^{2}(\mathbf{R}_{+}, d\xi ),\cssId{texmlid644}{\tag{36.21}}\\ \mathscr{F}_{e}f(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt {2\pi }}\left(\int _{\mathbf{R}}e^{-ix\xi }f(x)dx,\int _{\mathbf{R}}e^{ix\xi }f(x)dx\right). \end{align}$$

For $g =(g_{1},g_{2})\in L^{2}(\mathbf{R}_{+})\oplus L^{2}(\mathbf{R}_{+})$, the inverse map is

36.22 $$\begin{equation} \mathscr{F}_{e}^{-1}g(x) = \mathscr{F}_{e}^{*}g(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt {2\pi }}\left[\int _{\mathbf{R}_{+}}e^{ix\xi }g_{1}(\xi )d\xi +\int _{\mathbf{R}_{+}}e^{-ix\xi }g_{2}(\xi )d\xi \right]. \cssId{texmlid645}{\tag{36.22}} \end{equation}$$

With multiplicity 2, such a diagonalizing map is unique up to a map from $\sigma (L_{0})$ to $U(2)$. Again the wave operators single out two normalized eigenfunction expansions for $L$, connected this time by a map $\mathbf{R}_{+}\rightarrow U(2)$.
